comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
The date seems to say "9/15/1917" (written in white, backwards, after "Hook & Ladder #7" which starts from the right edge)

New York Times 9/14/1917 page 13:

"The death of fireman, 1st grade, G. Breler H. & L. 78, is announced.  Funeral will take place from 90 Hendricks St., New Brighton, at 8:30 A.M., Saturday, Sept. 15."

H&L = Hook and Ladder of course.  Address is on Staten Island.  Maybe that's enough for someone to figure out exactly where this was taken?

comment.author: 31042740@N00
comment._content:
It wasn't taken on Staten Island - there never were elevated train tracks here. The Fireman in the article most probably was from Staten Island. But how does that article relate to this photo?
That looks like Manhattan.
Thanks LOC for sharing!

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: I don't see a 1917 date in the inscription. It looks like the name of an intersection - "[illegible]  & 15"

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
@technogeo: You're right!  Random chance that the date I misread was the date of a fireman's funeral.

So is this the current High Line?

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: The fire engine is a 3-horsepower model.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content:
well perhaps someone knows where the Star Pharmacy is.  There's one in Harlem but seems situated in the middle of a hospital  

Harlem Star Pharmacy‎
67 West 137th Street, New York, NY 10037-19

There is also another team behind them, 2 firemen standing in the street, and another firewagon pointing the other way.  There is also fresh manure in several places, indicating they have been standing there a while.  Perhaps this was also part of the dedication for the fireman's memorial, since there are several pictures of that parade in the stream lately.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
"There is also fresh manure in several places, indicating they have been standing there a while."

From what I've seen (which isn't much) horses are pretty efficient at dropping road apples. "Bombs away," the moment they stop.

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
New York Times lists a "Star Pharmacy" at 317 9th Avenue in 1914.  Google puts 317 at around 28th/29th... not sure if addressing has changed?

The High Line didn't exist until the 30s, so 9th is a much better candidate.
